Virtuous ones!
There are four kinds of people in the world.
What are the four?ğŸ”½There may be someone who inwardly has impurity but does not know it, and does not know it as it truly is;
There may be someone who inwardly has impurity and knows it, and knows it as it truly is;
There may be a person who is actually free from defilements within but does not know it, and does not know as it truly is that they are free from defilements within;
there may be a person who is actually free from defilements within and knows it, and knows as it truly is that they are free from defilements within.
Virtuous ones!
If there is a person who is actually defiled within but does not know it, and does not know as it truly is that they are defiled within, this person is the most lowly among people.
If there is a person who is actually defiled within and knows it, and knows as it truly is that they are defiled within, this person is the most excellent among people.

If there is a person who is actually free from defilements within but does not know it, and does not know as it truly is that they are free from defilements within, this person is the most lowly among people.
If there is a person who is actually free from defilements within and knows it, and knows as it truly is that they are free from defilements within, this person is the most excellent among people.
Then, a certain monk rose from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, and with palms placed together he said to Venerable SÄriputta:
Venerable SÄriputta!
What are the causes and conditions for speaking of the first two people as both having defilements, with defiled minds, one being inferior and one being supreme?
What are the causes and conditions for speaking of the last two people as both being without defilements, with undefiled minds, one being inferior and one being supreme?
Then, Venerable SÄriputta replied to that monk:
Virtuous one!

If there is a person who truly has defilements within but does not know it, and does not know the truth of having defilements within, know that such a person does not wish to eliminate defilements, does not seek means, and does not diligently study, and they will then have defilements, with a defiled mind at the end of life;
Because they have defilements, with a defiled mind at the end of life, they will then die unvirtuously, and be reborn in an evil place.
Why is it so?
Because their minds are defiled by that impurity at the end of life.
Virtuous one!

It is just as if someone were to buy a copper vessel from a market or a copper shop, and it is defiled by dust and dirt. They bring it back and do not wash it frequently, do not wipe it frequently, do not expose it to the sun, and also place it in a dusty place. In this way, the copper vessel will increasingly receive dust and dirt.
Virtuous one!

In this way, if there is a person who internally has impurity but does not know it, and does not know it as it truly is, one should know that such a person does not wish to eliminate impurity, does not seek skillful means, and does not diligently study. They will then have impurity, and their minds will be defiled by that impurity at the end of life;
Because their minds are defiled by that impurity at the end of life, they will die unvirtuously and be reborn in an evil place.
Why is it so?
Because their minds are defiled by that impurity at the end of life.
Virtuous one!

If a person has impurity within themselves, and they truly know that they have this impurity within themselves, then know that person will seek to eliminate that impurity, will seek the means, will diligently study, and they will then be without impurity, and their mind will not be defiled at the end of life;
because of being without impurity, and their mind not being defiled at the end of life, they will die well and be reborn in a good place.
Why is it so?
Because of being without impurity, and their mind not being defiled at the end of life.
Virtuous one!

It is just as if a person were to buy a copper vessel from a market or a copper shop, and it were soiled with dust and dirt. They would take it and wash it again and again, wipe it again and again, sun it again and again, and not put it in a dusty place. In this way, the copper vessel would become extremely clean. Virtuous one!

In the same way, if someone has impurity within themselves and truly knows that they have this impurity within themselves, you should know that person will seek to cut off that impurity, seek the means, diligently study, and then be without impurity, with a mind not defiled at the end of life;
because of being without impurity, with a mind not defiled at the end of life, they will die well and be reborn in a good place.
Why is it so?
because of being without impurity, with a mind not defiled at the end of life.
Virtuous one!

If someone has no impurity within themselves but truly does not know that they have no impurity within themselves, you should know that person will not guard what is known by the eyes and ears. Because of not guarding what is known by the eyes and ears, they will be bound by lustful thoughts, and then have desire and impurity, with a defiled mind at the end of life;
because of having desire and impurity, with a defiled mind at the end of life, they will die unvirtuously and be reborn in an evil place.
Why is it so?
Because of having desire and defilement, with a defiled mind, one's life ends.
Virtuous one!

It is just as if someone were to buy a copper vessel from a market or a copper shop, which is clean and free from impurities. After receiving it, they do not wash it frequently, do not wipe it frequently, do not expose it to the sun frequently, and place it in a dusty place. In this way, the copper vessel will surely become covered in dust and dirt.
Virtuous one!

In the same way, if there is a person who has no defilements within themselves, but does not truly know that they have no such defilements within themselves, one should know that they do not guard the teachings known through the eyes and ears. Because of not guarding the teachings known through the eyes and ears, they become entangled by thoughts of desire, and then have desire and defilement, with a defiled mind, their life ends;
Because of having desire and defilement, with a defiled mind, their life ends, they then die unvirtuously, and are reborn in an evil place.
Why is it so?
Because of having desire and defilement, with a defiled mind, their life ends.
Virtuous one!

If a person internally has no defilements, and truly knows that they internally have no such defilements, one should know that they guard the precepts known by the eyes and ears. Because they guard the precepts known by the eyes and ears, they will not be bound by lustful thoughts. They will then be without desire and without defilements, with a mind that is not defiled at the end of life;
because they are without desire and without defilements, with a mind that is not defiled at the end of life, they will then die well and be reborn in a good place.
Why is it so?
Because they are without desire and without defilements, with a mind that is not defiled at the end of life.
Virtuous one!

It is just as if a person were to buy a copper vessel from a market or a copper smith, which is free from impurities and clean. After receiving it, they repeatedly wash and polish it, repeatedly sun it, and do not place it in a dusty place. In this way, the copper vessel becomes extremely clean.
Virtuous one!

In the same way, if someone internally has no defilements, and truly knows that they internally have no defilements, you should know that they guard the precepts known by the eyes and ears. Because they guard the precepts known by the eyes and ears, they are not bound by lustful thoughts. They then have no desire and no defilements, and their mind is not defiled at the end of life;
because they have no desire and no defilements, and their mind is not defiled at the end of life, they die well and are reborn in a good place.
Why is it so?
Because they have no desire and no defilements, and their mind is not defiled at the end of life.
Virtuous one!ğŸ”½For this reason and this cause, it is said that the previous two people both have defilements and a defiled mind, one is inferior and one is supreme.
For this reason and this cause, it is said that the latter two people both have no defilements and a non-defiled mind, one is inferior and one is supreme.
Then, another monk rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, placed his palms together facing Venerable SÄriputta, and said:

Virtuous one!
Countless evil and unwholesome states arise from desire, which is called 'defilement.'
Why is it so?
It may be that someone gives rise to such a desire in their mind:
'May no one else know that I have violated the precepts.'
Virtuous one!

It may be that someone else knows that they have violated the precepts. Because others know that they have violated the precepts, their mind will give rise to evil. If their mind gives rise to evil and desire, both are unwholesome.
Virtuous one!
It may be that someone gives rise to such a desire in their mind:
'May others reprimand me in private for violating the precepts, but do not reprimand me in the assembly for violating the precepts.'
' Venerable!

Venerable!
If someone gives rise to such a desire in their mind:
'I wish that my transgression of the precepts would be scolded by a superior person, not by an inferior person.'
Venerable!

If an inferior person scolds their transgression of the precepts, not a superior person, and they give rise to evil thoughts because of this, whether it is evil thoughts or thoughts of desire, both are unwholesome.
Venerable!
If someone gives rise to such a desire in their mind:
